This collaboration enhances the experience for Buzz Bingo members, encourages more visitors, and supports sustainable last-mile delivery solutions. By making parcel delivery more accessible, we are also strengthening connections within local communities and look forward to seeing how this partnership evolves. This is another successful step forward in the expansion of our open locker network across the UK, as we continue to seek new partnerships to provide safe and convenient parcel collection and drop-off solutions to everyone.” Quadient continues to expand its locker network across key markets in the United States, Japan, and Europe. With more than 25,000 units now installed worldwide, the company is steadily progressing toward its long-term goal of deploying 40,000 units globally by 2030. Learn more at parcelpending.com . Amazon to challenge postmen with parcel deliveries on foot Matthew Field Tue, Jan 14, 2025, 10:30 AM 4 min read In This Article: ROYMY 0.00% AMZN -0.11% Couriers will ditch their vehicles and carry packages on a handcart in a pilot programme across London - John Nguyen/PA Media Assignments Amazon is taking on the traditional postman by delivering parcels on foot. Couriers will ditch their vehicles and carry packages on a handcart in a pilot programme in the London boroughs of Hackney, Westminster and Islington. The new service, which is part of a wider effort to cut carbon emissions from Amazon’s fleet of delivery vans, means staff will cross paths with postal workers employed by the 509-year-old Royal Mail. Nicola Fyfe, of Amazon Logistics, said the business would consider expanding its on-foot deliveries to other UK cities if it proved a success. She said: “When you look at the on-foot walker deliveries, and couple them up with our electric bike deliveries and our electric vans – the three of them working together – really helps bring a sustainable delivery solution.” These three forms of zero-emission delivery now cover 70pc of London’s Congestion Charge zone, Amazon said. Ms Fyfe said it also helped when planning deliveries in pedestrianised zones and low-traffic networks. Amazon has also expanded its deliveries by electric cargo bike to Belfast and Norwich, joining London, Manchester and Glasgow. The technology giant has said it is investing £300m in cutting emissions from its UK delivery operations. Amazon has also expanded its deliveries by electric cargo bike in an attempt to reduce its carbon footprint - Matt Alexander/PA As part of this, Amazon said it would start transporting more packages by rail in Britain, beginning with the fully-electric West Coast Main Line between Scotland and the Midlands. Products will be unloaded from train carriages and sorted at local delivery centres. Royal Mail ended its “night mail” train service last year. The company also confirmed its largest ever order of electric HGVs on Tuesday, which will include 140 electric Mercedes Benz haulers and eight Volvo trucks. Its trucks will have a range of 310 miles on a full charge. The vehicles will expand Amazon’s fleet of green trucks to around 160. The order of electric trucks is a record for any company in the UK. Amazon said it expected the green transport to carry 300m packages each year once it is operational. It will also install fast-chargers at key points in its logistic network that can boost the batteries of its trucks from 20pc to 80pc in an hour. The company’s launch of on-foot deliveries in the UK follows similar trials in New York and Paris, where it has used people-power to avoid congestion and meet demands for next day and same day deliveries from customers. While it is a customer of the postal service, Amazon has a sprawling logistics division for deliveries from its Amazon.com site. It is also growing its shipping arm, which collects parcels from retailers directly and delivers them to customers, rather than sending them from a central fulfilment centre. Story Continues Despite being Britain’s biggest parcel company, Royal Mail has been grappling with a long-term decline in letter deliveries and a growing challenge from companies such as Evri and Amazon in parcels amid soaring demand for online shopping since the pandemic. Its postmen walk up to 1bn steps every day and half of the Royal Mail’s routes are largely on foot, with two-thirds of packages still delivered by legwork. Alexander Paterson, an analyst at Peel Hunt, said Royal Mail risked losing business to Amazon. He said: “Royal Mail has very high fixed costs and low margins even in good years, and is therefore very highly operationally geared. “If Amazon was to roll out its own delivery service in areas of high population density and high numbers of parcels per address, it would present challenges for Royal Mail.” Last year, the Government gave the green light to a £3.6bn takeover of Royal Mail by Czech tycoon Daniel Kretinsky. The postal service is also pushing for an overhaul of its universal service obligation, which requires it to deliver letters six days a week. Royal Mail is planning to trial a reduced service this year that will see some areas deprived of second-class letter deliveries on Saturdays. Botched rescue of Britain’s ‘second worst parcel courier’ Yodel sparks legal battle Luke Barr Fri, Dec 20, 2024, 9:53 PM 3 min read Yodel van A bitter High Court row has erupted over a botched rescue deal for delivery giant Yodel, as its drivers struggle to meet a Christmas surge in demand . Mike Hancox, the chief executive of Yodel, is spearheading a claim against 30-year-old entrepreneur Jacob Corlett, who had sought a merger with the company earlier this year. The action has been launched after talks between Yodel and Mr Corlett’s courier start-up Shift failed in the summer. Shift had submitted a proposal to rescue its larger rival and Mr Corlett was briefly appointed to the Yodel board. Mr Corlett’s backers have launched their own lawsuit against Mr Hancox and Yodel, understood to be related to fees lost from the collapsed deal. The spat is the latest sign of upheaval at Liverpool-based Yodel, which counts AO World, Argos and Zara among its customers, according to its website. The delivery business has recently been telling customers to use rival services as it struggles with capacity problems over Christmas . It has also repeatedly fared badly in customer satisfaction polls. Yodel was named second-worst courier company in the country in Ofcom’s latest survey, with Evri taking last place. Mr Corlett emerged as an unexpected “white knight” rescuer for Yodel in February after it was pushed to the brink under the ownership of the Barclay family. Doubts were cast over the company’s future in February when it emerged that insolvency experts at Teneo had been drafted in . At the time, the proposed deal with Shift was praised for saving thousands of jobs and securing Yodel’s future However, the merger was called off over the summer. Mr Hancox subsequently took control of Yodel with the backing of London-listed company PayPoint and specialist lender Independent Growth Finance (IGF). Yodel has since secured a £85m lifeline from its new backers. Court filings reveal that Yodel has issued a High Court claim personally against Mr Corlett, while also targeting his courier company Shift. A source close to the entrepreneur said: “The claims brought against Mr Corlett and his counterparts will be vigorously denied and defended, alongside the counterclaims being issued shortly.” The source added: “There are multiple parties that are very unhappy about Mike Hancox’s conduct in June and that’s manifesting itself in the issue of numerous lawsuits. “It remains to be seen if and how that litigation moves forward.” A Yodel spokesman said: “Yodel is aware of a number of groundless claims about our business being made by a former director which we refute in their entirety. “This director’s involvement in our business was short-lived and is now the subject of significant legal proceedings instigated by Yodel.” Story Continues In a separate but related case, investment bank Solano, which worked with Mr Corlett, is understood to be seeking lost fees from the proposed merger. It has hired law firm Mishcon de Reya to pursue breach of contract claims against Mr Hancox and Yodel. Bought by the Barclay family in 2010, Yodel struggled to gain traction in the delivery market in the face of fierce competition. The company lost £160m on revenues of £809m for the 18 months to December 2022, according to its latest results. The UK sector is dominated by five carriers – Royal Mail, Evri, Amazon Logistics, DHL and UPS – who together accounted for 71pc of the 14m parcels that were shipped in 2022, according to the Pitney Bowes Parcel Shipping Index. How Britain grew sick of ‘totally shameless’ delivery drivers Matthew Field Thu, Dec 19, 2024, 10:00 AM 7 min read In This Article: AMZN -0.11% parcel “Sorry we missed you”: four dreaded words that are all too common over the festive period. Everyone has a story of waiting diligently at home for a parcel to arrive only to spot a note on the doorstep or to see a text message claiming their delivery has gone awry. The run-up to Christmas is the busiest time for package deliveries across the country, with shoppers now far more reliant on online shopping than just a few years ago. There were 3.9bn parcel deliveries in 2023-24, compared to 2.8bn prior to Covid-19. Yet customer service levels have not kept pace with demand. Requests for help with lost packages were up 79pc in 2023 compared to 2019 data, according to Citizens Advice data. When things do go wrong, it can feel impossible getting a response out of delivery companies. Forty-eight per cent of people had a problem raising a complaint last year, the highest level in three years, Citizens’ Advice reports. The charity has warned of a “worrying trend of worsening customer service” among delivery companies. Across social media, stories abound of delivery firms sending photographic “proof” of delivery, only for parcels to disappear from porches. One Evri “delivery photo” shared with The Telegraph shows a pile of boxes in a sorting centre, rather than the package on the customer’s doorstep. Two-thirds of shoppers experienced a problem with a package delivery in the six months to July, according to data from Ofcom published earlier this year, representing millions of parcels that were missing, delayed or dumped in the wrong place. Among the worst offenders was Evri , with 44pc of parcel recipients reporting some kind of issue. Evri ranked particularly poorly when it came to complaints of drivers not knocking loud enough or leaving packages in random places. In Ring doorbell footage, reported by MailOnline earlier this month, an Evri driver can be seen throwing two packages by a customer’s doorstep before hurling a third over a nearby fence. An Evri spokesman said at the time: “This courier will no longer be delivering on behalf of Evri.” Other poor performers were Amazon, with 37pc of parcel customers experiencing an issue, TNT and Yodel. Royal Mail customers said they experienced a problem in 35pc of parcel deliveries. The companies with the least issues were DPD, Parcelforce – part of Royal Mail – and DHL. On Facebook, there are multiple groups with thousands of members complaining about Britain’s delivery companies. On the group “Yodel Delivery Are Utterly Useless”, one customer writes: “Yodel ‘pretended’ to have attempted a delivery. I was home, and I had CCTV showing that Yodel wasn’t even near my door. Totally shameless.” Story Continues The group “Evri Complaints and Advice (Unofficial)” has 76,000 members. (An Evri spokesman said the page dated back to 2020 and did not reflect significant investments made in the business since then.) Deep-rooted issues Why has customer service got worse as demand has increased? Industry experts say Britain’s parcel delivery network has suffered due to underinvestment. “This is a 10-year-old-plus problem that was getting increasingly worse due to a lack of investment,” says Phil Green, a former executive at Amazon, who spent eight years at US online retail giant. “UK parcel delivery was, and has long been, a problem and a reason why Amazon was forced to build its own operation in the UK rather than rely on other providers.” Amazon’s dominance has forced rivals to invest in their own infrastructure, piling financial pressure on their businesses. Industry analysts say package delivery companies have been caught in a “boom and bust” cycle. Many did well out of the pandemic, but invested poorly in new capacity and warehouses. At the same time, companies have been grappling with worker shortages. A report from retail technology business Esendex found there were 13,000 delivery driver jobs being advertised this Christmas along with 11,000 HGV driver roles, which are used to transport bulk packages to delivery hubs. Citizens Advice, meanwhile, says overworked and overstretched drivers often have just minutes to try to reach consumers, before either abandoning a package or leaving a note. With most couriers either on low wages or self-employed, there are few incentives to maintain high levels of customer service or hang around waiting for the door to open. In a 2021 report, Citizens Advice claimed: “Delivery drivers have high volumes of parcels to deliver each day and often encounter delays on the road. In addition, they’re often given short time frames, such as one or two minutes to deliver each parcel.” The report added that many drivers see part or all of their salaries made up of “pay-per-drop” fees – in some cases less than 50p per package – meaning they only get paid for a successful delivery. The structure potentially pushes drivers to dump packages or claim a delivery attempt was made, rather than trying again. Evri, which is owned by private equity giant Apollo, says its couriers earn an average of £17 per hour and this month it agreed a deal with the GMB union for parental leave, pensions, and holiday and sick pay for its self-employed drivers. However, self-employed drivers still need to pay for their own fuel and provide their own vehicles – in many cases passenger cars rather than vans. Overpromising and underdelivering Other experts suggest retailers also have a role to play in letting down consumers. Many are eager to promise quick and easy next-day deliveries to compete with services like Amazon Prime. “Retailers, certainly over the Christmas period, are overpromising,” says Jonathan De Mello of JDM Retail. Citizens Advice has called for tougher penalties for the industry when service falls short. It argues that current regulations are not up to scratch and Ofcom is failing to pressure companies into taking their responsibilities to customers seriously. Anne Pardoe, head of policy at the charity, says: “Our research shows alarming numbers of people have to chase lost, late or damaged parcels – and those with accessibility needs are still being overlooked by delivery companies. “Ofcom needs to start investigating companies whose complaints processes are still not up to scratch and take enforcement action if necessary. “Ultimately, Ofcom must look more closely at the rate of delivery problems people are experiencing and, where necessary, fine the worst offenders if they fail to improve.” Evri said it had invested £32m in its operations this year, including in making it easier to contact people. A spokesman said: “The Citizens Advice survey shows we are one of the most improved parcel delivery firms over the past four years, while Ofcom recently stated high levels of consumer satisfaction with Evri’s service. “This year we will deliver around 800m parcels, with more than 99pc arriving on time, and we are proud to be the only parcel delivery company that mandates proof-of-delivery photos for every parcel. Customers and retail clients are voting with their feet and trust us with their deliveries.” A Yodel spokesman said: “The overwhelming majority of the 200m parcels we handled over the last 12 months were delivered correctly on the first attempt. “We work tirelessly to make improvements, especially to the accessibility of our services, where we include options for customers to divert deliveries, encourage delivery preferences to be added and share any specific requirements or issues with us via the Yodel app.” An Ofcom spokesman says parcel delivery companies need to have a “transparent complaints process in place, if for example you need to complain about something you’ve sent, or the behaviour of a delivery driver”. The spokesman added: “Last year, we strengthened our complaints guidance, and have been speaking to companies to understand how they’re improving their service.” Amazon declined to comment. TNT was approached for comment. Despite claims of improvement, almost a quarter of customers are still unsatisfied with the level of service. Shoppers will be hoping for more Christmas cards than “sorry we missed you” cards this festive season. Broaden your horizons with award-winning British journalism. The epidemic of ‘porch piracy’ that threatens to ruin Christmas James Titcomb Thu, Dec 19, 2024, 10:00 PM 6 min read Footage of a man stealing a parcel Credit: Facebook/Spotted: Crawley/Sophie Burke All good Christmas stories have their villains. Charles Dickens has Ebeneezer Scrooge, Dr Seuss has The Grinch, Die Hard has Hans Gruber. Today, time-pressed families doing their festive shopping online have a very modern enemy: the skulking porch pirate. This antagonist, recognisable by their tightly drawn hoodie, may not have the theatrical flourish of their literary counterparts, but are no less threatening. A surge in online deliveries over recent years, especially during the Christmas period, have led to a spate of reports about package thieves swiping boxes from porches and behind bins before their rightful recipient can retrieve it. According to Quadient, a parcel logistics company, the value of package theft in Britain has reached an all-time high in the last 12 months, with £376.6m of goods stolen. Consumer research from the company combined with Freedom of Information requests to UK police forces estimated that there were 10,910 reports of theft in the last year, although it said that only a tiny fraction of cases of stolen packages are reported to the police. Predictably, cases spike in December. The company said that 13pc of households have had a parcel stolen in the last year, and that those living in blocks of flats are more likely to be victims than those in houses, since thieves tend to target communal areas where a large number of parcels might be available to steal at once. Quadient’s services include selling delivery lockers , so it stands to benefit from increased fears about porch theft, but concerns about the issue are rising, largely due to a surge in internet shopping. E-commerce boomed during lockdowns, and since then, many households have retained their pandemic shopping habits. Online retail accounted for 27.1pc of all spending last December, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), against pre-Covid levels of 19.7pc. It is expected to grow again this year. Experian is predicting another 4.4pc rise in online shopping this Christmas, to £28bn. But even if we are shopping as if it is 2020, we are not living in the same way. More employers are demanding workers return to the office five days a week, meaning people are no longer at home on Mondays and Fridays to collect packages. John Hayward-Cripps, the chief executive of Neighbourhood Watch, says package theft is increasingly being brought up in its groups, alongside burglary and anti-social behaviour. “It has become a much more significant issue in the past five years,” he says. Researchers say porch piracy is a poorly understood crime, in part because it rarely gets reported, and also because in most cases consumers are entitled to refunds or replacements when an item fails to make its way to them. Story Continues One analysis of YouTube porch theft videos, by researchers at Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU), found that thefts were typically pre-meditated rather than the result of an individual randomly walking past a package placed outside the front door. One or two people, typically in a vehicle, would pass a property several times to observe it before pouncing. In several cases, thieves posed as delivery drivers (in one case wearing a FedEx jacket) or carried a clipboard when approaching the property and often rang the doorbell or knocked on the door, so as not to arouse neighbours’ suspicions. Few attempted to conceal their identity and package thieves were evenly split between men and women. Ben Stickle, a professor of criminal justice at MTSU, says companies have speculated that the most professional thieves have access to either a company’s systems or victim’s accounts, allowing them to track the most valuable packages and grab them as soon as they are placed on the doorstep. Clothing, particularly shoes, and electronics are the most likely to be targeted. The researchers said that measures such as security cameras appeared to have little effect, even when they had been clearly spotted by the thieves. This has not stopped a surge in video doorbell purchases across Britain, in part due to security concerns. According to figures from Ofcom, 22pc of households now have a smart doorbell, up from 5pc in 2020. Among the proposals for countering thefts was removing branding from boxes, making them less enticing. But the most obvious solution was simply for them to not be visible from the street – a matter that comes down to the delivery driver. Charities have blamed delivery companies for a swathe of missing and stolen parcels. Citizens Advice says 24pc of complaints about parcel deliveries concern the package being left in an insecure location. In 2021, the charity said drivers, who are often gig economy workers particularly during the Black Friday and Christmas periods, were overworked. It has said that drivers paid on a per-delivery basis are incentivised to leave parcels in unsafe places, and called for delivery companies to be covered by “Essential Condition” regulations, which can impose fines for lost or stolen packages, and which currently only apply to Royal Mail . Delivery companies have disputed this claim. Amazon said the company had introduced a string of measures, such as giving customers delivery windows, allowing them to specify hidden drop-off locations, share tracking with friends and family, and have items delivered to lockers or local businesses . “We know how important it is for customers to get their packages and the vast majority of deliveries make it to customers without issue,” an Amazon spokesman said. “As well as providing a number of delivery options, we use notification and tracking technology to help customers keep tabs on their orders and ensure packages arrive as expected.” Evri said that it took other factors such as customer satisfaction into account when paying drivers. “Our teams of hard-working couriers are currently delivering up to 4m parcels a day, with more than 99pc delivered on time, and parcel security is a top priority,” a spokesman said. “We provide proof of delivery photos for every parcel, using AI to provide direct feedback to couriers on image quality or if a parcel appears to be in an unsafe location. “We closely track delivery standards and what we pay our couriers is based not just on the number of parcels delivered, but also the standard of their deliveries and the satisfaction of customers delivered to.” DPD and Yodel did not respond to requests for comment. MTSU’s Stickle says that many delivery operators are unlikely to be aware of how many packages are reported stolen, since most contact is between the customer and the retailer. “There’s a huge disconnect with data sharing on this issue. And so that’s why a lot of the time we don’t know the scope of the problem.” Even if its extent is unclear, increasing levels of internet shopping mean package theft is only likely to become more apparent. Unlike many of their fellow Christmas villains, the porch pirate is unlikely to have a seasonal change of heart. Broaden your horizons with award-winning British journalism. How Royal Mail’s decline sparked a multibillion-pound battle to control Christmas James Warrington Wed, Dec 18, 2024, 10:01 AM 7 min read In This Article: ROYMY 0.00% Illustration: Royal Mail When Yodel realised it did not have enough drivers to cover the Christmas rush, it took an unusual step. The delivery company earlier this month told its customers – including eBay and New Look – to use rival couriers instead. The decision underscores the challenges facing Yodel, which has frequently come under criticism for its poor quality of service. More widely, though, it highlights the unprecedented demand for parcel delivery services as people increasingly do their Christmas shopping online. A booming and growing market has sparked cut-throat competition among couriers. With incumbent Royal Mail losing ground, a crop of new players has sprung up looking to capitalise on the e-commerce boom. At stake are billions of pounds in revenues from lucrative Christmas contracts. Winning such deals will deliver for investors – but will it deliver for customers? When Royal Mail was privatised in 2013, parcels were cited as a key opportunity in the new era for Britain’s postal service. Posties would benefit from the boom in online shopping, investors were told. “Rather than picking winners in e-commerce, you knew that as long as people were buying physical stuff it would still need to be delivered,” says Gerald Khoo, an analyst at Panmure Liberum. But rather than thrive, the 500-year-old Royal Mail has been weighed down by the onerous universal service obligations, which require it to deliver letters on Saturdays and meet strict quality of service targets, as well as the high costs of its heavily unionised workforce. Instead, Royal Mail has seen its dominant market share eroded. It faces tough competition from the likes of DPD and DHL, while newer players such as Yodel and Evri, formerly known as Hermes, have begun to gain ground. “It’s a growth market, so there’s capital chasing that growth, wanting to get involved,” says Alexander Paterson at Peel Hunt. “You have an incumbent in Royal Mail who has been probably under-invested in for the last four or five years, if not potentially longer, and therefore other groups sense they can take market share and do that through innovation and technology.” Amazon, meanwhile, began building its in-house delivery network across the UK in a bid to drive more customers to its Prime subscription service. The US retail giant is now the second-largest courier in the country behind Royal Mail. Its high-speed service, which offers same-day delivery for some orders, has also raised customers’ expectations. Khoo describes this as a “double whammy”. He says: “Amazon added capacity and took volumes away from everyone else, which resulted in structural over-capacity in the market. I don’t think that situation has resolved.” Story Continues Parcel volumes were already rising before the pandemic struck but Covid-19 drove demand to record highs. Couriers invested heavily in infrastructure such as warehouses and sorting centres to meet this spike in demand, which saw 4bn parcels sent in 2020-21. As lockdown restrictions eased, however, parcel volumes fell back. Growth finally returned in the year to March, when 3.9bn parcels were sent and overall revenues stood at £13bn, according to figures from Ofcom. For some smaller players, the damage was already done. Yodel was saved from collapse by rival Shift in a last-minute rescue deal in February. “Parcel services I wouldn’t say are in trouble, but they’re not financially as viable as they were during Covid,” says retail analyst Jonathan De Mello. “It’s definitely not a happy ship with some of these businesses. I think they over-invested in their logistics during Covid and then spend dropped off a cliff the following year.” Yet as demand peaks over the Black Friday and Christmas period, it is still all to play for. Rival couriers vie for lucrative contracts with the likes of John Lewis, Marks & Spencer and Asos, though major retailers often work with multiple delivery firms. For Royal Mail, which starts preparing for Christmas immediately after Easter, the peak season is critical. The company hires hundreds of seasonal workers, opens temporary mail sorting centres and has previously offered bonuses to staff as an incentive. This year, for example, Royal Mail is hiring an additional 16,000 people for the festive period, taking its total number of posties to over 100,000. That compares to around 28,000 delivery drivers at Evri. Royal Mail uses this added capacity as leverage, locking some customers into year-long deals in return for access to its peak Christmas service. The postal company also specialises in smaller parcels, which tend to be most in demand for festive gifts. Czech tycoon Daniel Kretinsky has made it clear that parcels will be the focus when he takes over the Royal Mail - Roman Vondrous/CTK Daniel Kretinsky, the Czech tycoon who has been given the green light for a £3.6bn takeover of Royal Mail , has made it clear that his focus is on parcels. He plans to invest around £800m rolling out 20,000 parcel lockers across the country where customers can pick up deliveries, hoping to undercut rivals on price. Even Martin Walsh, who represents more than 100,000 Royal Mail employees at the Communication Workers Union, this week acknowledged the need for change. “This industry does not survive if we don’t grow parcels,” he said. But Royal Mail, which lost £349m last year and is still recovering from recent crippling strikes, has its own challenges. The company is campaigning for an overhaul of its universal service obligations, warning that current regulations have rendered its business model financially unsustainable. Its rivals operate from a much lower cost base and often have deeper pockets to invest in new technology. As Khoo puts it: “Royal Mail is playing catch-up in every single aspect.” In a highly competitive market, however, pricing power is limited. As a result, parcel delivery companies must find ways to stand out. Savvy operators have carved out a niche in the market, for example, by providing premium high-speed deliveries or specialising in large, bulky items. They are also locked in a billion-pound battle over customer service. “We’ve seen pressure on the parcel services to deliver a quality of service that matches what the merchants are promising,” says De Mello. “And I think there’s an increased dichotomy between merchants promising we’ll get it to you before Christmas and then the parcel services maybe not delivering that.” Frustrated consumers will be all too aware that it is the retailer who chooses the courier, not the customer. Nevertheless, service standards still matter. Merchants who frequently miss their delivery targets risk driving customers away and suffering revenue losses. “If they don’t deliver – especially to an M&S or a John Lewis – then they stand to lose some of that business,” De Mello adds. “That’s why there’s so much pressure on them to deliver on time.” Despite the challenges, investors are still betting on future growth. Evri was snapped up by US private equity giant Apollo in a £2.7bn deal in July and has since outlined a plan to hire 9,000 new workers to meet rising parcel demand. Paterson predicts a wave of consolidation as smaller regional players are bought up or shut down, particularly if regulations are tightened. “For me, parcels are a good structural growth market,” he says. “It’s one that’s consolidating and where the returns I would expect to be very attractive over a long period of time. It’s a very good area for investors to be in.” Festive spending is expected to hit £22.7bn this year, according to PwC. With appetite for online shopping showing no signs of abating, couriers are jostling for a share of the spoils. Christmas still delivers the biggest payday of the year. The first 250 lockers will be opened in early 2025, making it easier for customers to drop off parcels. The first site is already open outside the company’s Mount Pleasant mail centre in Clerkenwell, central London. The lockers, which will be located outside delivery offices and third-party retailers, will give round-the-clock access for customers sending parcels. The service will include label-printing, aimed at supporting the growing number of people selling clothes and other items on second-hand online marketplaces. Royal Mail said the locker service will be expanded to allow parcel collection in the near future, meaning customers can pick up packages at their convenience, rather than having to wait at home for a delivery. It comes as Royal Mail steps up its focus on parcels amid a continued decline in letter sending. Over the last two decades, annual letter volumes have declined from 20bn to 7bn and are expected to fall further to just 4bn in five years’ time. Around 70pc of Royal Mail’s revenues now come from parcels. However, the postal service has been losing market share to Amazon, as well as rival couriers such as DPD, Evri and InPost. Royal Mail began expanding its network of parcel points earlier this year. Customers can drop off parcels at 1,000 shared lockers and more than 5,000 Collect+ points in convenience stores across the country. However, the launch is the first time the company has provided access to dedicated lockers only for its customers, which it said will improve capacity and service. Jack Clarkson, at Royal Mail, said: “With continued growth in online shopping, we are expanding our range of services for customers to make sending and receiving parcels more convenient than ever. “Parcel lockers are just one of the ways that we will achieve this, and with their growth in popularity, it is important that we have our own lockers to offer a modern, quick and convenient option for our customers. “The rollout of Royal Mail lockers is good news for online shoppers, small businesses sending their orders and the UK public in general.” It comes as Czech billionaire Daniel Křetínský closes in on a £3.6bn takeover of Royal Mail.
